DOC.HEAD: Administration Says EEC Proposal Will Spur Farm Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: A proposal by the European Economic Community to overhaul agricultural trade will clear the way for final negotiations with the EEC in 1990, the Bush administration said. ``This is the last of the major proposals to be submitted and now will permit the final negotiations on agriculture to get under way early next year,'' said U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. However, they added in a joint statement Wednesday, certain aspects of the EEC proposal cannot be accepted by the United States. The comprehensive EEC proposal was made in Geneva in the Uruguay Round of trade talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The GATT negotiations are scheduled to conclude at the end of 1990. ``While the proposal contains some positive indications, we are concerned with the continued reliance by the (EEC) on managed agriculture and, in particular, the apparent intention to continue to rely upon large-scale subsidies and especially export subsidies,'' the leaders said. ``Government programs that manage markets are one of the major causes of the current trade distortions in agriculture,'' they said. ``The successful future of trade in agriculture depends on market liberalization and significant reduction of subsidies that distort trade.'' The United States cannot accept the EEC proposal to ``rebalance'' import protection, Mrs. Hills and Yeutter said. ``Rebalancing would raise tariffs, reduce market access and increase the price of food to consumers,'' they said. ``Rebalancing is simply protectionism by another name, and we believe the other GATT countries will recognize it as such.'' Mrs. Hills and Yeutter said the EEC approach ``does little to liberalize market access'' and that the 12-nation bloc's position on export subsidies is ``unacceptably weak and totally out of step'' with other proposals made in the talks.
